sen.j: 出雲大神宮（いずもだいじんぐう）は、京都府亀岡市にある神社である。
sen.e: Izumo Daijingu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Izumo Daijingu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Izumo Daijingu Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社（名神大社）、丹波国一宮。
sen.e: It is the Ichinomiya (highest ranking shrine) of Tamba Province listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).
It is the Ichinomiya (highest ranking shrine) of Tamba Province listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).
It is the Ichinomiya (highest ranking shrine) of Tanba Province listed in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era) (Myojin Taisha).

sen.j: 旧社格は国幣中社で、第二次世界大戦後は神社本庁などの包括宗教法人に属さない単立となっている。
sen.e: It was ranked as a Kokuhei Chusha under the old shrine classification system and became independent of any comprehensive religious corporations such as the Association of Shinto Shrines following the Second World War.

It was ranked as a Kokuhei Chusha under the old shrine classification system and became independent of any comprehensive religious corporations such as the Association of Shinto Shrines following the Second World War.

It was ranked as a Kokuhei Chusha under the old shrine classification system and became independent of any comprehensive religious corporations such as the Association of Shinto Shrines following the World War II.
sen.cmt: OK第二次世界大戦 用語統一

sen.j: 旧称を出雲神社。
sen.e: The shrine was previously named Izumo-jinja Shrine.
The shrine was previously named Izumo-jinja Shrine.
The shrine was previously named Izumo-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 「元出雲」の通称があり、背後に「千年山」という神体山があることから「千年宮」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is generally referred to as "Moto Izumo" and "Sennen-gu" due to the "Sennenyama" mountain in which the deity was traditionally believed to dwell to the rear of the shrine.
It is generally referred to as "Moto Izumo" and "Sennen-gu" due to the "Sennenyama" mountain in which the deity was traditionally believed to dwell to the rear of the shrine.
It is generally referred to as 'Moto Izumo' and 'Sennen-gu' due to the Mt. Sennen mountain in which the deity was traditionally believed to dwell to the rear of the shrine.

sen.j: いわゆる出雲大社は明治時代に至るまで杵築大社を称していたため、江戸時代末までは、出雲神社と言えばこの出雲大神宮を指していた。
sen.e: Until the Meiji era, Izumo Taisha Shrine was named "Kizuki Taisha Shrine" and therefore the name "Izumo-jinja Shrine" referred to this Izumo Taisha Shrine until the end of the Edo period.
Until the Meiji era, Izumo Taisha Shrine was named "Kizuki Taisha Shrine" and therefore the name "Izumo-jinja Shrine" referred to this Izumo Taisha Shrine until the end of the Edo period.
Until the Meiji period, Izumo Taisha Shrine was named Kizuki Taisha Shrine and therefore the name Izumo-jinja Shrine referred to this Izumo Taisha Shrine until the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 吉田兼好が徒然草の第236段で記した「丹波に出雲と云ふ処あり」の「出雲」とはこの神社のことである。
sen.e: The "Izumo" described by Kenko YOSHIDA in the 236th column of Tsurezuregusa (Essays in Idleness) which reads "There is a place called 'Izumo' in Tamba" refers to this particular shrine.
The "Izumo" described by Kenko YOSHIDA in the 236th column of Tsurezuregusa (Essays in Idleness) which reads "There is a place called 'Izumo' in Tamba" refers to this particular shrine.
The 'Izumo' described by Kenko YOSHIDA in the 236th column of Tsurezuregusa (Essays in Idleness) which reads 'There is a place called Izumo in Tanba' refers to this particular shrine.

sen.j: また、地元でも混同されがちだが亀岡市下矢田町にある出雲大社京都分院とは別である。
sen.e: Confusion may arise with regard to names but this shrine is different from the Izumo Taisha Kyoto Branch Shrine in Shimoyada-cho, Kameoka City.
Confusion may arise with regard to names but this shrine is different from the Izumo Taisha Kyoto Branch Shrine in Shimoyada-cho, Kameoka City.
Confusion may arise with regard to names but this shrine is different from the Izumo Taisha Kyoto Branch Shrine in Shimoyada-cho, Kameoka City.

sen.j: 祭神
sen.e: Enshrined Deities
Enshrined Deities
Enshrined deities

sen.j: 現在は大国主と三穂津姫（みほつひめのみこと）を主祭神とし、天津彦根命・天夷鳥命を配祀するとしている。
sen.e: The main enshrined deities are Okuninushi no mikoto and Mihotsuhime no mikoto which are enshrined along with Amatsuhikone no mikoto and Amenohinatori no mikoto.
The main enshrined deities are Okuninushi no mikoto and Mihotsuhime no mikoto which are enshrined along with Amatsuhikone no mikoto and Amenohinatori no mikoto.
The main enshrined deities are Okuninushi no mikoto and Mihotsuhime no mikoto which are enshrined along with Amatsuhikone no mikoto and Amenohinatori no mikoto.

sen.j: 大国主命は別名 三穂津彦大神・御蔭大神としている。
sen.e: Okuninushi no mikoto is also known by the names Mihotsuhiko no okami and Mikage no okami.
Okuninushi no mikoto is also known by the names Mihotsuhiko no okami and Mikage no okami.
Okuninushi no mikoto is also known by the names Mihotsuhiko no okami and Mikage no okami.

sen.j: 三穂津姫尊はタカミムスビの子で、大国主の国譲りの際に大国主の后となったと伝えている。
sen.e: Mihotsuhime no mikoto is the daughter of Takamusubi and legend states that she became the empress of Okuninushi during his transfer of the land.
Mihotsuhime no mikoto is the daughter of Takamusubi and legend states that she became the empress of Okuninushi during his transfer of the land.
Mihotsuhime no mikoto is the daughter of Takamusubi and legend states that she became the empress of Okuninushi during his transfer of the land.

sen.j: 当社の祭神については、天津彦根命・天夷鳥命・三穂津姫命の三柱とする説や、元々は三穂津姫尊一柱のみであるという説もある。
sen.e: One theory claims that the three deities Amatsuhikone no mikoto, Amenohinatori no mikoto and Mihotsuhime no mikoto are enshrined at Izumo Daijingu Shrine, whereas an alternative theory claims that originally only Mihotsuhime no mikoto was enshrined.

One theory claims that the three deities Amatsuhikone no mikoto, Amenohinatori no mikoto and Mihotsuhime no mikoto are enshrined at Izumo Daijingu Shrine, whereas an alternative theory claims that originally only Mihotsuhime no mikoto was enshrined.

One theory claims that the three deities Amatsuhikone no mikoto, Amenohinatori no mikoto and Mihotsuhime no mikoto are enshrined at Izumo Daijingu Shrine, whereas an alternative theory claims that originally only Mihotsuhime no mikoto was enshrined.

sen.j: 大国主命については、出雲国の出雲大社（杵築大社）から勧請したとされるが、逆に出雲大社の方が当社より勧請を受けたものとする説もあり、俗に「元出雲」とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is believed that Okuninushi no mikoto was separated and transferred from Izumo Taisha Shrine (Kizuki Taisha) in Izumo Province but there is also the theory claiming that it was in fact the reverse and that the deity of Izumo Taisha Shrine was transferred from Izumo Daijingu Shrine, which is colloquially referred to as "Moto Izumo".

It is believed that Okuninushi no mikoto was separated and transferred from Izumo Taisha Shrine (Kizuki Taisha) in Izumo Province but there is also the theory claiming that it was in fact the reverse and that the deity of Izumo Taisha Shrine was transferred from Izumo Daijingu Shrine, which is colloquially referred to as "Moto Izumo".

It is believed that Okuninushi no mikoto was separated and transferred from Izumo Taisha Shrine (Kizuki Taisha) in Izumo Province but there is also the theory claiming that it was in fact the reverse and that the deity of Izumo Taisha Shrine was transferred from Izumo Daijingu Shrine, which is colloquially referred to as 'Moto Izumo.'

sen.j: 『丹波国風土記』には、「元明天皇和銅年中、大国主命御一柱のみを島根の杵築の地に遷す」との記述がある。
sen.e: "Tamba no Kuni Fudoki" (A Topography of Tamba Province) records that "Emperor Genmei transferred Okuninushi no mikoto alone to the land of Kizuki in Shimane during the Wado era (708-715)".
"Tamba no Kuni Fudoki" (A Topography of Tamba Province) records that "Emperor Genmei transferred Okuninushi no mikoto alone to the land of Kizuki in Shimane during the Wado era (708-715)".
"Tanba no Kuni Fudoki" (A Topography of Tanba Province) records that 'Emperor Genmei transferred Okuninushi no mikoto alone to the land of Kizuki in Shimane during the Wado era (708-715).'

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 創建の年代は不詳であるが、社伝では和銅2年（709年）10月21日に社殿を建立したと伝える。
sen.e: The exact time that Izumo Daijingu Shrine was founded is not known but according to shrine legend, the shrine was constructed on the 21st day of the 10th month of the year 709.
The exact time that Izumo Daijingu Shrine was founded is not known but according to shrine legend, the shrine was constructed on the 21st day of the 10th month of the year 709.
The exact time that Izumo Daijingu Shrine was founded is not known but according to shrine legend, the shrine was constructed on November 30, 709.

sen.j: 国史の初見は『日本紀略』の弘仁8年（818年）12月16日条「丹波国桑田郡出雲社、名神に預る」という記述であり、この時代にはすでに有力な神社になっていたことがわかる。
sen.e: The first historical reference to the shrine appears in "Nihongi Ryaku" (Summary of Japanese Chronologies) in an article for the 16th day of the 12th month of the year 818 which states "Izumo-sha Shrine in Kuwata County, Tamba Province has a rank of Myojin Taisha" - indicating that the shrine was already influential by this point in history.

The first historical reference to the shrine appears in "Nihongi Ryaku" (Summary of Japanese Chronologies) in an article for the 16th day of the 12th month of the year 818 which states "Izumo-sha Shrine in Kuwata County, Tamba Province has a rank of Myojin Taisha" - indicating that the shrine was already influential by this point in history.

The first historical reference to the shrine appears in "Nihongi Ryaku" (Summary of Japanese Chronologies) in an article for the 16th day of the 12th month of the year 818 (old lunar calendar) which states 'Izumo-sha Shrine in Kuwata County, Tanba Province has a rank of Myojin Taisha' - indicating that the shrine was already influential by this point in history.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では名神大社に列している。
sen.e: It is the listed as a Myojin Taisha in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).
It is the listed as a Myojin Taisha in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).
It is the listed as a Myojin Taisha in the Jinmyocho (Register of Deities) of the Engishiki (procedures of the Engi era).

sen.j: 正応5年（1292年）には神階が最高位の正一位まで昇った。
sen.e: In 1292, the shrine was granted the highest possible rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
In 1292, the shrine was granted the highest possible rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).
In 1292, the shrine was granted the highest possible rank of Shoichii (Senior First Rank).

sen.j: 社殿
sen.e: Buildings
Buildings
Buildings

sen.j: 現在の社殿は、足利尊氏によって貞和元年（1345年）に改修されたものと伝え、国の重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: The current main sanctuary was repaired by Takauji ASHIKAGA in 1345 and has been nationally designated an Important Cultural Property.
The current main sanctuary was repaired by Takauji ASHIKAGA in 1345 and has been nationally designated an Important Cultural Property.
The current main sanctuary was repaired by Takauji ASHIKAGA in 1345 and has been nationally designated an Important Cultural Property.

sen.j: かつては36社の摂末社を有していたが、兵火により失われ、現在は上の社、黒太夫社、笑殿社、春日社、稲荷社、崇神天皇社の6社がある。
sen.e: There were once 36 auxiliary and subsidiary shrines but these were lost to fires arising from various conflicts so that now only the six shrines Kami-no-yashiro, Kurodayu-sha, Shoden-sha, Kasuga-sha, Inari-sha and Sujin Tenno-sha remain.

There were once 36 auxiliary and subsidiary shrines but these were lost to fires arising from various conflicts so that now only the six shrines Kami-no-yashiro, Kurodayu-sha, Shoden-sha, Kasuga-sha, Inari-sha and Sujin Tenno-sha remain.

There were once 36 auxiliary and subsidiary shrines but these were lost to fires arising from various conflicts so that now only the six shrines Kami-no-yashiro, Kurodayu-sha, Shoden-sha, Kasuga-sha, Inari-sha and Sujin Tenno-sha remain.
